The Emergency Response Plan is reviewed annually and updated, as needed. The ERP is also revised based on deficiencies from drills or incidents.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Polynt works with employees, vendors, and corporate EHS support staff and incorporates corrective actions identified through programs, such as mechanical integrity inspections, incident investigations, compliance audits and PHA studies to continually improve the safety of processes.  Polynt will continue to evaluate and document analyses of safer technologies.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no releases in the past five years that require reporting under the RMP Program. 
 All incidents and near misses with the potential to cause any injury or damages are investigated with a team of experienced personnel.  Reports are developed for all TDI incidents. Reports include, at a minimum, injuries, fatalities, personnel evaluated, and included in shelter in place, impact on the environment, emergency response actions, and cause(s). The regulations require the reporting of RMP events involving regulated substances that result in deaths, injuries or significant property damage on site, or known deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage off-site or other off-site consequences. 

The facility maintains an accurate list of all TDI near misses and incidents. This is used during revisions to the plant Emergency Response Plan, employee training, Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs), and procedures. When there is a RMP accident, the facility notifies regulatory agencies. The facility will also plan and hold a public meeting within 90 days following the RMP accident. 


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Polynt has a comprehensive Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that is coordinated with St. Louis County Emergency Management and Valley Park Fire Department.  The ERP provides clear roles and responsibilities, procedures, and corrective measures to be used in the event of an emergency that could threaten human health or the environment. ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

Polynt is dedicated to continuous improvement of its comprehensive Environmental, Health and Safety (EH&S) Program, which includes compliance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management regulations (29 CFR 1910.119). Employees are highly trained, knowledgeable, and skilled, which results in a workforce that is very capable in their job performance. Employees are supplied with detailed information concerning their job duties, chemicals on site, and operating the processes. The OSHA Process Safety Management Program is used to identify, correct, review, and mitigate potential hazards associated with chemical processes.  Employee participation in the development and implementation of these programs is essential to ensure employee understanding and compliance with each element of the programs.

Polynt has developed a strong Contractor Safety and Management Program. Contractors and their employees are treated as though they are Polynt employees, while performing work at the Valley Park facility. Contractors are trained on Polynt processes and procedures, expected to participate, as necessary, in incident investigations, and are held to the same standards of performance as Polynt employees.

POLYNT ACCIDENTAL RELEASE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Polynt Composites USA, Inc. (Polynt) is committed to operating the Valley Park facility in a manner that is safe for our employees, the community, and the environment.  As part of this commitment, Polynt has established a Risk Management Program that helps the company to identify and communicate risks associated with our operations and reasonable controls have been established to prevent accidental releases from occurring.  In the unlikely event of a release of hazardous materials from the facility, specific plans are in place to reduce the effects upon our employees and the general public.  Polynt has developed site-specific plans for emergency response that involve both our employees and local emergency service providers.  These plans are in compliance with the U.S. EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) plan requirements and follow the format provided by the RMP Data Elements published by the U.S. EPA (EPA form 8700-25).


PROCESSES AND SUBSTANCES SUBJECT TO 40 CFR PART 68

Polynts Valley Park facility uses toluene diisocyanate (TDI), to produce a variety of urethane coatings and other resins.  TDI is onsite in quantities greater than the applicability threshold and therefore is subject to the RMP regulation.  In addition to TDI, Polynt uses numerous other chemicals that are not subject to the RMP regulation.

Physical security of the plant is maintained by a chain link fence topped by barbed wire that encompasses the site. Site activities are monitored by 23 TV cameras, with monitor screens located in the guard house and other plant computers. A security guard is on duty 24 hours a day, seven days a week.
